title: How are myths created? What are some examples? - Quora

response.answer_text: Myths are the stories we tell ourselves to give us a view of personal and shared reality, and whether they are justifiably true, in any historical or scientific sense, is not usually considered. Myths are very powerful forces in any culture and are often more powerful than anything science can reveal. For example, myths tell and teach us what it means to be a man or woman, lover or friend, husband or wife, honest or deceitful, brave or cowardly, and the many other seemingly inscrutable ways of being, that we personally and culturally presume to be real. This nuanced definition of myth is well beyond the notion that a myth is a widely held belief, but nevertheless false. The comparative mythologist, Joseph Campbell said, “Every myth is psychologically symbolic. Its narratives and images are to be read, therefore, not literally, but as metaphors.” Campbell, J. (2002). The Inner Reaches of Outer Space: Metaphor as Myth and as Religion. Novato, CA: New World Library. p. 28). These mythic metaphors become so personally innate that it is often difficult to recognize them in any meaningful way without a great deal of reflection, sometimes helped by education or pursuing psychological insights. Relatable to innate cognitive biases, the myths expressed by storytelling can be so powerful as to reinforce, for example, the prejudice bias such that a person is unable to self consciously recognize themselves to be racist, sexist or ethnocentric. To understand the powerful significance that possibly innately held mythic metaphors play in culture, consider the ramifications of what Joseph Campbell means when he says: “Half the people in the world think that the metaphors of their religious traditions, for example, are facts. And the other half contends that they are not facts at all. As a result we have people who consider themselves believers because they accept metaphors as facts, and we have others who classify themselves, as atheists because they think religious metaphors are lies.” Campbell, J. (2001). Thou Art That: Transforming Religious Metaphor. Collected Works of Joseph Campbell. New World Library. Retrieved from: Thou Art That Quotes Looking at the rising ethno-religious conflicts around the world today leaves little doubt that possibly innate and intractable mythic metaphors are driving many of these horrors. According to the Pew Research Center, in 2018: “The share of countries with “high” or “very high” levels of social hostilities involving religion remained stable at 27%. Countries in these two categories scored at least a 3.6 on the Social Hostilities Index, a 10-point scale based on 13 measures of social hostilities involving religion, including tensions between religious groups and religion-related terrorism. Although the share of countries in these categories did not change since last year, it was higher than in 2007, when this study began tracking social hostilities. In addition, several countries joined these top two categories of social hostilities in 2016. Bangladesh experienced an increase in assaults and killings of members of religious groups by social groups or individuals – including multiple instances where people who had expressed atheist views or were accused of offending Islam on the Internet were killed or threatened.” Kishi, K. (2018, June 21). Key findings on the rise in religious restrictions. Pew Research Center. Retrieved from: Key findings on global rise in religious restrictions in 2016

I can’t account for all myths, but I can offer two: Paul Bunyan and Davy Crockett. Although many Americans think the Paul Bunyan stories were based on the feats of a real person, he was actually created by two lumber-industry public relations men named James Stevens and W. B. Laughead as a way to publicize their lumber company. He was no more a real person than is Harry Potter. The first mention of Paul Bunyan in print occurred in 1914. He has been conflated with “John Henry, the steel drivin’ man” as a symbol of what happens to talented individuals as a result of progress. Both Paul Bunyan and John Henry were put out of work because machines could do more work, faster, than they could. David Crockett (the name he apparently preferred to Davy) was a real person, a Tennessee frontiersman and three-term Congressman who died at the Alamo. Stories about him were like today’s political ads shown on TV, a way to become known to voters at a time when travel and communication on the frontier were difficult.
